comments:
Often when Eclipse is "thinking" is redraws its main Window's
title bar hundreds of times a second - and does this for
"extended periods" - several seconds.

This probably slows things down further - and gives the impression
to the user that either Eclipse has crashed - or else that some
bad programming has taken place.

The effect is common - but not terribly repeatable or reproducible.
Can you give me an idea of what Eclipse is 'thinking' about?  Is it doing a 
build, importing projects?  I haven't noticed this on XP here but will ask 
around.  Also, which build are you using?  Is there anything in the .log file 
to indicate something has gone wrong?  Do you have any other tasks (non-
Eclipse) running at the same time?
One time when it happens is just after saving a file - i.e.
during compilation.

I'm on:

 Version: 2.1.0
 Build id: 200303272130

...but this has happened with every other build of Eclipse I've tried.

I have a 700Mhz machine.

One other possibly-relevant factor is that I tend to use the Eclipse
checkstyle plugin.

I figured this problem happens to everyone - but I may be
mistaken about that.

I have a 2.1Mb log file - most of which is not very comprehensible to me.
Nothing looks immediately suspicious.

There were a lot of:

Yes, I tend to run other things at the same time.
Tim,

You can delete or move the .log file somewhere else (depending on whether or 
not you want to keep the information in there).  Then, when you see the 
problem happening again, you won't have such an unmanageable amount of data.

Am transferring to JDT UI to see if they have any comments wrt calls to 
MouseClickListener.repairRepresentation(...)

It's hard to tell from the stack trace. The text problem could be a follow up of
the NPE.

Please reopen if you still get this using R2.1 or higher.
